title: Diagnosing COVID-19 Severity from Chest X-Ray Images Using ViT and CNN Architectures
author: Luis Lara (Universite de Montreal), Lucia Eve Berger (Universite de Montreal), Rajesh Raju (Universite de Montreal), Shawn Whitfield (Universite de Montreal), ...
background: This research focuses on predicting the severity of COVID-19 in patients by analyzing chest X-ray images using advanced machine learning techniques.
contribution: This paper introduces a large dataset of COVID-19 severity scores and compares the performance of various models (Vision Transformers and Convolutional Neural Networks) to improve severity prediction accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily classified COVID-19 as present or absent or focused on severity prediction without extensive datasets.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by combining multiple datasets to enhance the size and diversity of training data while utilizing advanced architectures like Vision Transformers for better prediction accuracy.

key_innovation: Leverages a combination of transfer learning and a new dataset to enhance the predictive capability of machine learning models for COVID-19 severity assessment.
real_world_impact: The findings could significantly improve clinical decision-making in healthcare settings by enabling more precise patient triage based on imaging data, potentially saving lives and resources.

new_terms.Vision Transformer (ViT): **Vision Transformer (ViT)** is a type of deep learning model that applies transformer architecture to image data, allowing it to learn spatial relationships between pixels through self-attention mechanisms.

open_sourcing: The project's source code is publicly available on GitHub.
